#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=6. HIF and Vascular Diseases
#Text=In vascular pathology , hypoxia is typically the consequence of altered , destroyed or absent blood vessels leading to tissue ischemia .

#Text=The mechanisms of the HIF response have therefore been studied in ischemic vascular diseases , such as myocardial infarction ( consequence of obstruction of coronary arteries ) or peripheral vascular disease ( PAD , consequence of obstruction of arteries going to the limbs ) .

#Text=Besides tissue ischemia , mechanisms of hypoxia and ischemia can occur within the vascular wall itself , with implications for diseases such as atherosclerosis , arterial aneurysm , chronic venous insufficiency and thromboembolism .

#Text=There is growing evidence that the HIF pathway is implicated — for better or for worse — in the response of the vascular wall to inadequate oxygenation and/or increased cellular oxygen , a demand secondary to various stresses or injuries .
#Text=6.1 .
#Text=HIF and Atherosclerosis
#Text=Atherosclerosis is a condition in which fatty deposits ( plaques ) develop in the arterial wall , leading to stenosis and ultimately to thrombosis of the vessel .
#Text=Atherosclerotic plaques are mainly composed of cholesterol , other lipids , calcium , fibrin and inflammatory cells .
#Text=Oxygen diffusion through space-occupying atherosclerotic plaques could be limited due to wall thickening .
#Text=Hypoxia could also originate from the high oxygen demand of metabolically active inflammatory cells , such as macrophage foam cells that play a pivotal role in this disease .

#Text=Detection of HIF-1α and activation of its target genes occurs in atherosclerotic plaques . During atherogenesis ( plaque build-up ) , hypoxia increases angiogenesis , releases pro-inflammatory mediators , activates MMPs , forms reactive oxygen species , and oxidizes low-density lipoprotein .
#Text=Necrotic cores within atherosclerotic plaques can lead to plaque instability and thromboembolic complications .
#Text=The HIF-1α protein is found in tissue surrounding atherosclerotic arteries , inflammatory macrophages and arterial SMCs around these necrotic cores .
#Text=Proangiogenic HIF-target genes , such as VEGF-A , are responsible for intra-plaque neoangiogenesis , contributing to plaque instability .
#Text=HIF-1 activity also alters the lipid metabolism of macrophages and vascular SMC .
#Text=Finally , besides hypoxia , several non-hypoxic stimuli of HIF have also been found in plaques and plaque macrophages , such as inflammation , ROS , vasoactive and thrombotic factors .
#Text=6.2 .
#Text=HIF and NH in Vascular Grafts
#Text=The role of the HIF pathway in the development of NH has also been studied .
#Text=When atherosclerotic lesions occupy a long segment of the artery , surgeons frequently use a graft to bypass the lesion and provide blood to distal tissues .
#Text=Either venous or prosthetic , these grafts are prone to NH .

#Text=Although vein grafts and prosthetic grafts are not identical , because of different hemodynamics and oxygen tension , the characteristics of NH in vein grafts are similar to those of NH that form in AVFs .
#Text=In studies with animal models , grafts showed increased hypoxia within the vessel wall in regions of neointimal hyperplasia .

#Text=A study using a porcine model showed an association of HIF-1α expression with the degree of neointimal hyperplasia in grafts , and suggested that reducing hypoxia might inhibit venous NH formation , possibly by reducing the phenotypic switch of fibroblasts to myofibroblasts .

#Text=Paradoxically , increased activation of the HIF pathway may also protect against NH formation . Nakao et al. studied the role of carbon monoxide , a physiologically important vasodilator that acts via cyclic guanosine monophosphate , in the formation of NH .
#Text=They showed that a vein graft placed immediately after harvest led to less NH than if the graft was rinsed with lactated Ringer for 2 h prior to surgical placement .
#Text=However , if the lactated Ringer solution was saturated with carbon monoxide , it significantly inhibited NH compared to the untreated control .
#Text=The effects of carbon monoxide in inhibiting NH formation seemed to be associated with increased HIF-1α and VEGF expression a few hours after grafting .

#Text=This effect , including the induction of VEGF , was reversed by treatment with YC-1 , a HIF-1α inhibitor , supporting the conclusion that these effects were mediated through the activation of the HIF pathway .

#Text=These apparently contradictory studies suggest that , at least in the setting of vein graft NH , transient activation of the HIF pathway may protect the wall from hypoxia , whereas chronic activation may maintain the ongoing NH process .

#Text=Carbon monoxide may also display vasoconstrictor effects depending on oxygen and metabolic homeostasis , including ROS production , highlighting the important role of metabolism in the vascular wall .
